Technical Assistance Report 
 
Project Number: 52050-001 
Knowledge and Support Technical Assistance (KSTA) 
October 2018 
 
 
 
 
 
Supporting Knowledge Solutions in Central and West 
Asian Countries
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
This document is being disclosed to the public in accordance with ADB’s Public Communications 
Policy 2011.

ABBREVIATIONS 
 
ADB  –  Asian Development Bank 
CAREC  –  Central Asia Regional Economic Cooperation 
CWRC  –  Regional Cooperation and Operations Coordination Division 
CWRD  –  Central and West Asia Department 
DMC  –  developing member country 
ERCD  –  Economic Research and Regional Cooperation Department 
KPSs  –  knowledge products and services 
NSO  –  national statistical office 
NTF  –  near-term forecasting 
PRC  –  People’s Republic of China 
SNA  –  system of national accounts 
TA  –  technical assistance 
 
 
NOTE 
 
In this report, “$” refers to United States dollars. 
 
 
Vice-President  Wencai Zhang, Operations 1 
Director General  Werner Liepach, Central and West Asia Department (CWRD) 
Director  Safdar Parvez, Regional Cooperation and Operations Coordination 
Division, CWRD 
   
Team leader  Lyaziza Sabyrova, Principal Regional Economist, CWRD 
Team members  Lilia Aleksanyan, Economist, CWRD  
  Irene de Roma, Associate Programs Officer, CWRD  
  Mahinthan Joseph Mariasingham, Statistician, Economic Research 
and Regional Cooperation Department (ERCD) 
Madhavi Pundit, Economist, ERCD 
Arief Ramayandi, Senior Economist, ERCD 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
In preparing any country program or strategy, financing any project, or by making any designation 
of  or  reference  to  a  particular  territory  or  geographic  area  in  this  document,  the  Asian 
Development Bank does not intend to make any judgments as to the legal or other status of any 
territory or area.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  The regional knowledge and support technical assistance (TA) will help deliver knowledge 
solutions to Central and West Asia Department (CWRD) countries. The Asian Development Bank 
(ADB) has identified promoting knowledge solutions for its developing member countries (DMCs) 
as a strategic priority.1 The TA will help fulfill this priority by generating, facilitating, and enabling 
knowledge solutions in CWRD countries. 
 
2.  The TA will provide demand-based and just-in-time knowledge products and services 
(KPSs) to CWRD countries and facilitate knowledge and experience exchange between CWRD 
countries and other countries of interest.2 Further, based on needs expressed by CWRD countries, 
the TA will support improved data for evidence-based policy making and assist selected middle-
income CWRD countries with innovative near-term forecasting (NTF) techniques. The TA will 
coordinate closely with ADB’s Economic Research and Regional Cooperation Department (ERCD) 
and will draw lessons from previous ADB operations. 
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
3.  Need for knowledge solutions. CWRD covers a diverse range of countries in Central 
Asia, South Asia, and South Caucasus: four lower middle-income countries (Georgia, the Kyrgyz 
Republic, Pakistan, and Uzbekistan); four upper middle-income countries (Armenia, Azerbaijan, 
Kazakhstan, and Turkmenistan); low-income (Tajikistan), and a low-income and post-conflict 
country  (Afghanistan).3 These  DMCs  face many  common, region-wide,  and  country-specific 
constraints on economic and social development. Almost all Central Asian and South Caucasus 
countries face low economic diversification, dependency on natural resources or on remittances, 
weak rule of law, and rising inequality. To help address these issues, CWRD DMCs are turning 
increasingly to ADB for knowledge solutions. 
 
4.  Focused,  relevant,  demand-driven,  and  timely  knowledge  solutions  are  critical  to 
addressing these development constraints and enhancing the quality of people’s lives. Knowledge 
support—including policy analysis, formulation, and implementation as well as capacity building 
and learning from other countries’ experiences—is just as important for the region’s low-income 
countries as it is for middle-income countries and is demanded by various players, including 
governments, public and private think tanks, and other institutions. 
 
5.  Consultations with CWRD authorities and national think tanks revealed strong interest in 
sharing knowledge and relevant experiences between CWRD countries and with successful 
reformers elsewhere, such as with the People’s Republic of China (PRC) on poverty reduction and 
economic management. CWRD needs a suitable mechanism for sharing experiences between 
CWRD countries and with other DMCs. Such learning and sharing of experiences on broad and 
demand-driven issues—in the spirit of South-South knowledge exchange—will help develop 
nation-focused knowledge solutions. 
                                                
1  ADB. 2018. Strategy 2030: Achieving a Prosperous, Inclusive, Resilient, and Sustainable Asia and the Pacific. Manila. 
ADB’s forthcoming knowledge action plan, 2019–2023 calls for ADB to become a demand-responsive yet proactive 
knowledge organization and aims at promoting transfer of technologies and best practices; sharing knowledge, skills, 
and expertise; and deepening knowledge partnerships. These documents and the President’s Planning Directions for 
2018 also call for a stronger collaboration culture within ADB that allows for stimulating and sharing knowledge. (ADB 
[Office of the President]. 2018. Planning Directions for 2018 and Preparation of Work Program and Budget Framework, 
2019–2021. Memorandum. 23 February [internal]). 
2  The TA first appeared in the business opportunities section of ADB’s website on 12 October 2018. 
3   World Bank. Country classification by income level: 2018-2019 (https://datahelpdesk.worldbank.org).

2 
6.  Need for improved data for evidence-based policy making. In the complex and dynamic 
development  landscape  of  CWRD  countries,  continuous  monitoring  of  major  social  and 
macroeconomic trends and issues is vital for proper economic analysis and policy making aimed 
at ensuring economic growth and inclusiveness. To provide data for such evidence-based policy 
making, the national statistical offices (NSOs) in CWRD countries need significantly improved 
capacity and capability.4 While most NSOs in the region have benefited from earlier support from 
other development partners, including the ADB, significant gaps and needs remain, including in 
compiling national accounts, global and regional value chain indicators, labor market indicators 
such as self-employed persons, Sustainable Development Goals, and various disaggregated data. 
 
7.  In almost all CWRD countries, macroeconomic data are released with substantial delay, 
and some key indicators are not available at all.5 Moreover, low-frequency data such as annual 
national accounts often rely on a small number of surveys and indicators and provide only a partial 
picture of the economy. In such a context, proper macroeconomic forecasting is significantly 
impaired. Current advances in economic forecasting practices, however, allow the construction of 
reliable forecasts based on the use of higher-frequency data (e.g., monthly, weekly, or daily 
indicators) and/or the use of big data.6 NTF is increasingly employed by policy makers throughout 
the world to analyze the current state of an economy and predict its near future direction. Several 
NSOs in CWRD’s middle-income countries have started employing these techniques but require 
further assistance to advance their use. 
 
8.  The TA will address these issues and challenges through tailored, timely, and flexible 
support for the emerging knowledge needs in CWRD countries. The TA will use experiences and 
lessons from relevant ADB assistance and analyses and will collaborate closely with ERCD 
activities.7 The TA will also coordinate closely with development partners and think tanks in each 
CWRD  country  and  with  the  Asian  Development  Bank  Institute  and  Central  Asia  Regional 
Economic Cooperation (CAREC) Institute activities.8 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
9.  The TA is aligned with the following impact: economic and social policy making in CWRD 
DMCs improved. The TA will have the following outcome: analytical capacity and capability in 
CWRD DMCs enhanced.9 
                                                
4  NSOs here refer to national statistical agencies and other government entities that produce official statistical data, 
such as central banks in relation to balance of payment or monetary statistics. 
5  In many CWRD countries, the first estimate of quarterly gross domestic product is released 45 days after the end of 
the quarter. 
6  Big data refers to the large structured and unstructured data sets arising from people’s digital transactions with 
computers, social media, mobile phones, satellite images, and other types of digital technology. 
7  These include the following: ADB. 2013. Technical Assistance to the Republic of Kazakhstan for the Joint Government 
of Kazakhstan and the Asian Development Bank Knowledge and Experience Exchange Program, Phase 1. Manila; 
ADB. 2015. Technical Assistance to the Republic of Kazakhstan for the Joint Government of Kazakhstan and the 
Asian Development Bank Knowledge and Experience Exchange Program, Phase 2. Manila; ADB. 2015. Technical 
Assistance for Strengthening Knowledge Management in Central and West Asia. Manila; ADB. 2015. Technical 
Assistance for Knowledge Development Support for Southeast Asia. Manila; ADB. 2016. Technical Assistance to the 
People’s Republic of China for the Facility for Strengthening Policy Reform and Capacity Building. Manila; and 
Independent  Evaluation  Department.  2017.  Knowledge,  Finance,  and  the  Quality  of  Growth:  An  Evaluation 
Perspective on Strategy 2030. Manila: ADB. 
8  The CAREC 2030 strategy recognizes the CAREC Institute as the knowledge arm of the CAREC program to serve 
the knowledge needs of CAREC member countries. (ADB. 2017. CAREC 2030: Connecting the Region for Shared 
and Sustainable Development. Manila). 
9  The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1.

3 
B.  Outputs, Methods, and Activities 
 
10.  Output 1. Timely and relevant knowledge solutions delivered. This output will expand 
the delivery of demand-based and just-in-time KPSs to CWRD countries.10 The TA will expand 
assistance  to  support  relevant  requests  from  public  and  private  think  tanks  and  analytical 
institutions in CWRD countries, in addition to government requests. It will also support in-country 
discussions on priority economic policy issues among policy makers, think tanks, the private sector, 
and development partners.11 
 
11.  In addition, in response to frequent requests from authorities and analytical institutions in 
CWRD countries, the TA will help develop a suitable mechanism for sharing knowledge and 
experiences between CWRD countries and with other DMCs.12 It will draw on lessons and 
experiences from the CAREC Program’s knowledge sharing, the ADB–PRC Regional Knowledge 
Sharing Initiative, and other similar mechanisms.13  
 
12.  Output 2. Data for evidence-based policy making improved. This output will provide 
tailored support to NSOs in CWRD countries, based on the identified needs and gaps for evidence-
based policy making and modernizing national statistical systems. Preliminary identification of 
country needs in the system of national accounts (SNA)—the fundamentals of official statistics—
demonstrated that most SNA statistics in CWRD countries do not conform with the 2008 SNA 
standards.14 Principal users of official data such as other government agencies, think tanks, 
investment banks, donor partners, and academics often complain of the generally low quality and 
reliability of official data, as well as inadequate access to the data.15 In addition to the overall need 
to further implement the 2008 SNA recommendations, the specific challenges identified in various 
CWRD countries included constructing and improving the constant price Supply and Use Tables 
and Input–Output Tables, the capital formation segment of the SNA, and bilateral trade matrixes 
within the SNA. 
 
13.  The TA will coordinate closely with and complement assistance to NSOs under the TA for 
Data for Development.16 Although the ongoing work primarily focuses on the SNA, the TA may 
consider other areas of support in line with identified country-specific needs, including labor 
statistics, especially on self-employed persons; indicators for regional and global value chains; 
improvements in administrative data and their integration into the SNA; or indicators relevant to 
                                                
10 Several demand-based KPSs were supported under a regional TA project (ADB. 2015. Technical Assistance for 
Strengthening Knowledge Management in Central and West Asia. Manila). They included support for studies, 
conferences, capacity development, and purchase of software in CWRD countries, ranging between $3,000 and 
$98,000 for each KPS. These KPSs were well received by the governments and other stakeholders, which expressed 
the need to continue such assistance and expand their scope. 
11 Examples include requests to support brainstorming events in Kazakhstan under the Astana Economic Club or the 
establishment of a similar network in Uzbekistan. 
12 Topics raised during consultations included lessons on pitfalls of economic reforms from the earlier liberalizers in 
Central Asia and South Caucasus for Uzbekistan, which recently embarked on significant economic reforms; the 
experiences of Armenia, Kazakhstan, and the Kyrgyz Republic’s membership in the Eurasian Economic Union; the 
experiences of resource-rich economies such as Azerbaijan and Kazakhstan in economic diversification; and lessons 
for CWRD countries from the PRC’s successful experience in poverty reduction. 
13 ADB–PRC Regional Knowledge Sharing Initiative. 
14 United Nations Statistics Division. System of National Accounts 2008. The 2008 SNA is the latest version of the 
international statistical standard for the national accounts, adopted by the United Nations Statistical Commission. 
15 Preliminary identification of the needs and gaps took place for several countries jointly with ERCD during the Inception 
Forum and Training on the 2008 SNA under the TA for Data for Development for CAREC countries (ADB. 2017. 
Technical Assistance for Data for Development. Manila). The TA will undertake separately an assessment of needs 
and gaps for Afghanistan, Armenia, and Turkmenistan, which were not present at the Inception Forum. 
16 ADB. 2017. Technical Assistance for Data for Development. Manila.

4 
ADB operations.17 For each country, the TA will prioritize areas of assistance based on the impact 
on evidence-based policy making, synergies and efficiency from collaboration with the TA for Data 
for Development, and ADB’s comparative advantages and coordination with other development 
partners.  This  output  will  strengthen  the  analytical  capacity,  methodologies,  and  data 
dissemination of NSOs. Regional activities will be undertaken as appropriate where feasible. 
 
14.  Output 3. Near-term forecasting techniques improved in selected middle-income 
Central and West Asia Department countries. Innovative NTF or nowcasting techniques are 
useful because they allow for more timely forecasts of macroeconomic indicators, which are 
typically released with substantial lags, by using higher-frequency data to predict more recent but 
so far unobserved values.18 Several NSOs in CWRD countries, such as the central banks of 
Armenia and Kazakhstan, have started using these advanced techniques, but informed ADB that 
they require further assistance to improve their model formulation, specification, and use of data. 
The TA will explore innovative use of big data for evidence-based policy making and collaborate 
closely with ERCD work on nowcasting techniques.19 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
15.  The TA is estimated to cost $750,000, which will be financed on a grant basis by ADB’s 
Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF-other sources). The key expenditure items are listed in 
Appendix 2. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
16.  ADB will administer the TA. CWRD's Regional Cooperation and Operations Coordination 
Division (CWRC) will implement the TA, working closely with CWRD resident missions and ERCD. 
For output 1, KPS requests will be routed through the resident missions to CWRC and will be 
considered  following  established  procedure.20 CWRC  will  evaluate  requests  based  on  their 
expected contribution to filling knowledge gaps identified in DMC country knowledge plans, and 
rank requests based on funding availability and the comparative urgency of proposals. Resident 
missions will implement all aspects of the approved KPSs, including recruitment and supervision 
of consultants, procurement, and TA funds disbursement. Outputs 2 and 3 will be implemented by 
CWRC,  which  will  select,  supervise,  and  evaluate  consultants;  organize  workshops  and 
conferences; and monitor overall TA implementation. 
 
17.  Consulting services. The TA will be implemented from January 2019 to December 2020. 
ADB will engage about 22 person-months of international and 20 person-months of national 
consulting services during the TA implementation period. International consultants will include 
statisticians, experts in the 2008 SNA and other relevant areas, data scientists or experts, and 
nowcasting experts. National consultants will include economists, statisticians, and data analysts. 
ADB may also engage international and national resource persons to provide inputs, review 
reports, and participate as presenters, facilitators, and/or discussants in meetings and workshops. 
                                                
17 One emerging area is related to the identification and profiling of subgroups of the population in CWRD countries that 
are increasingly left out in terms of benefits from economic growth. 
18 Nowcasting uses various indicators to provide concurrent updates on gross domestic product growth; it uses 
substantial volumes of data directly and indirectly related to economic activity. Nowcasting often uses factor models, 
which are based on the notion that the dynamics of a large set of time series data is driven by a small number of 
common factors; these factor models extract such common signals from the large number of observations. 
19 For  example,  under  ADB.  2013.  Technical  Assistance  for  Macroeconomic  Modeling  for  Improved  Economic 
Assessment. Manila. 
20 Procedure for Demand-Based Knowledge Products and Services Assistance (accessible from the list of linked 
documents in Appendix 3).

5 
 
18.  ADB  will  recruit  consultants  as  individuals  because  of  the  potentially  wide  range  of 
expertise required, the specific country knowledge, and the need to closely coordinate with 
consultants under the TA for Data for Development. ADB will engage consultants following the 
ADB Procurement Policy (2017, as amended from time to time) and its associated project 
administration instructions and/or staff instructions.21 The TA funds will be disbursed following 
ADB’s Technical Assistance Disbursement Handbook (2010, as amended from time to time). 
 
19.  ADB’s procurement. Procurement will follow the ADB Procurement Policy (2017, as 
amended from time to time) and Procurement Regulations for ADB Borrowers (2017, as amended 
from time to time). 
 
19.  The implementation arrangements are summarized in the table.

Source: Asian Development Bank. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
 
21.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $750,000 on a grant basis for 
Supporting Knowledge Solutions in Central and West Asian Countries, and hereby reports this 
action to the Board. 
                                                
21 Terms of Reference for Consultants (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 3).

Appendix 1  7 
Key Activities with Milestones 
1.  Timely and relevant knowledge solutions delivered to CWRD DMCs 
1.1 Receive KPS requests through CWRD resident missions (January 2019–September 2020) 
1.2 Review and approve KPS requests (January 2019–September 2020) 
1.3 Engage consultants and/or resource persons as needed to implement the KPSs (February 2019–
September 2020) 
1.4. Monitor the implementation of the KPSs (February 2019–October 2020) 
1.5. Disseminate the KPSs as appropriate (February 2019–October 2020) 
1.6. Discuss and agree on the appropriate knowledge and experience sharing mechanism (January–
March 2019) 
1.7. Conduct knowledge and experience sharing events (February 2019–October 2020) 
1.8. Disseminate the results of the knowledge and experience sharing events (February 2019–October 
2020) 
 
2.  Data for evidence-based policy making improved in CWRD countries 
2.1 Identify the pressing gaps and needs in the national statistical systems of Afghanistan, Armenia, and 
Turkmenistan (January–June 2019) 
2.2. Coordinate with the TA for Data for Development and identify the assistance to provide to CWRD 
DMCs, with a view of ensuring maximum complementarity (January–December 2019)b 
2.2. Provide capacity building support to selected CWRD DMCs for improving and/or modernizing their 
national statistical systems (January 2019–October 2020) 
 
3.  NTF techniques improved in selected middle-income CWRD DMCs 
3.1. Identify the required assistance to the central banks of Armenia and Kazakhstan in advancing NTF 
techniques and scope out the need in other relevant CWRD countries (February–April 2019) 
3.2. Engage consultants and provide required support for NTF techniques to these selected countries 
(March–December 2019) 
3.3. Disseminate the results of this work in other interested CWRD DMCs (January–June 2020)
